title: The sixth-century chronicler count Marcellinus, Chronicle A.C. 476/Ind. 14, relates that “Odoacer sentenced Augustulus, son of Orestes, to the punishment of exile (exilium) in Lucullanum, a fortress in Campania.” It is tempting, based on this phrasing, to say that the western Empire concluded in exile. Jordanes, The Origin and Deeds of the Goths 242 (sixth century) expresses the same sentiment. However, it is not clear from the Anonymus Valesianus 2.8.37–38 that Romulus’s condition was a formal version of exilium.
